instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message: This board had some type of oil spilled on it. The computer was pretty coated. The board had no corrosion on it but had some oil on it. I ran it through the ultrasonic cleaner and it came out working fine except it doesn't recognize the SSD. Any ideas where to look with something like this? The SSD connector is attached on J9600 and has no visible damage to it or around it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message: Post voltages on power pins, enable and clock request of J9600.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message: I measured the wrong pad. <SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_L</SIGNAL> is actually the one at 1.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message:
Check for continuity on J9600.
It must have the same voltages on both sides (PCH and SSD), for all signals and power lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message: Continuity is good on all pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message: I did find that the voltage drop to ground on <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_LB_L</SIGNAL> was slightly low compared to a good board. I replaced <CHIP>U8601</CHIP> and it's measuring normal now. 3.3V also on that line. All pins on both sides of J9600 are measuring normally. I've also checked all SSD voltages. They're fine. Nothing visibly damaged in the area although it definitely got hit by the oil or whatever it was.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message: I'm about to let this one go. Anyone have any other possible directions to go with this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message:
Do you get clock signal for SSD?
<SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> should be low to enable clock, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> is at .09V but I'm not sure where to check for a clock signal for the SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
threads.message: Any suggestions for finding and reading the clock signal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not recognizing SSD
